skills.name: Multiplication, division and power law of indices with positive integer powers
Multiply algebraic terms, involving non-linear versions of the same letter (e.g. 4a² x 2a)
Multiply algebraic terms, involving non-linear versions of different letters (e.g. 4a² x 5ab)
Divide algebraic terms, involving non-linear versions of the same letter (e.g. 4a² ÷ 2a)

explanations.A: Not quite! Remember, when we have an index inside the brackets and another outside, we multiply the indices together. Also, think carefully about what happens to the indices when we divide!
explanations.B: You've done the division part correctly, well done. Think carefully about what happens when we raise an index to another power (outside the brackets). If you aren't sure, try writing it out in full.
explanations.C: I think you've multiplied the powers inside and outside the brackets correctly, giving you 5 to the power of 24. But think carefully about what we need to do when we divide!
explanations.D: 5 to the power of 6, all to the power of 4 is the same as 5⁶ x 5⁶ x 5⁶ x 5⁶ which gives 5 to the power of 24. When we divide by an index, we subtract the powers, so we do 24 - 2. The answer is 5 to the power of 22, therefore n is 22.

explanations.A: I think you've multiplied the powers inside and outside the brackets correctly, giving you 7 to the power of 32. But think carefully about what we need to do when we divide!
explanations.B: 7 to the power of 8, all to the power of 4 is the same as 7⁸ x 7⁸ x 7⁸ x 7⁸ which gives 7 to the power of 32. When we divide by an index, we subtract the powers, so we do 32 - 2. The answer is 7 to the power of 30, so n is 30.
explanations.C: Not quite! Remember, when we have an index inside the brackets and another outside, we multiply the indices together. Also, think carefully about what happens to the indices when we divide!
explanations.D: You've done the division part correctly, well done. Think carefully about what happens when we raise an index to another power (outside the brackets). If you aren't sure, try writing it out in full.

explanations.A: 5p² can be thought of as 5 x p x p and 2p as 2 x p. We therefore have 5 x p x p x 2 x p. As multiplication is commutative, the order of this calculation does not matter. Therefore 5 x 2 x p x p x p, gives 10p³.
explanations.B: You've multiplied the letters correctly. Just think carefully about what we are doing to the 5 and the 2 in this calculation.
explanations.C: You've multiplied the 5 and the 2 but don't forget to multiply p² by p.If you aren't sure, write out each of the terms in full and then multiply them.
explanations.D: We can simplify this expression by multiplying the terms together. If you aren't sure, think about 5p² as being 5 x p x p and 2p as being 2 x p and go from there!

explanations.A: Can you remember the rule for when we multiply indices? If you aren't sure, write out each term in full, for example 2p² would be 2 x p x p. Then multiply them together.
explanations.B: We can think of 3p³ as being 3 x p x p x p and 2p² as being 2 x p x p. As multiplication is commutative, the order of the calculation does not matter so we can do 3 x 2 x p x p x p x p x p. This gives 6p⁵ which is p to the power of 5, multiplied by 6.
explanations.C: You've multiplied the letters correctly. Just think carefully about what we are doing to the 3 and the 2 in this calculation.
explanations.D: We can simplify this expression. We can multiply these terms together. If you aren't sure, think about 3p³ as being 3 x p x p x p and 2p² as being 2 x p x p and go from there!

explanations.A: Nearly! Think about what happens when you calculate 6 ÷ 2.
explanations.B: We can divide the coefficients giving us 6 ÷ 2 = 3, so the new coefficient will be 3. To divide the indices we need to subtract the powers. So p to the power of 6 ÷ p to the power of 2 gives p to the power of 4, because 6 - 2 = 4 . Therefore, the answer is 3p⁴.
explanations.C: You have divided 6 by 2 correctly but think carefully about how we calculate p to the power of 6 divided by p to the power of 2. Try writing each index in full before you divide. For example p⁶ = p x p x p x p x p x p.
explanations.D: We can simplify this expression by dividing the terms. If you aren't sure, think about 6p⁶ as being 6 x p x p x p x p x p x p and 2p² as being 2 x p x p and go from there!

explanations.A: Nearly! Think carefully about what happens when you divide the coefficients, 6 ÷ 3.
explanations.B: You have divided 6 by 3 correctly but think carefully about how we calculate p to the power of 6 divided by p to the power of 3. Try writing each index in full before you divide. For example p⁶ = p x p x p x p x p x p.
explanations.C: We can divide the coefficients giving us 6 ÷ 3 = 2, so the new coefficient will be 2. To divide the indices we need to subtract the powers. So p to the power of 6 ÷ p to the power of 3 gives p to the power of 3, because 6 - 3 = 3 . Therefore, the answer is 2p³.
explanations.D: We can simplify this expression by dividing these terms. If you aren't sure, think about 6p⁶ as being 6 x p x p x p x p x p x p and 3p³ as being 3 x p x p x p and go from there!

explanations.A: I think you might have written 5 x 5 as 5² and then added the powers when raising this to the power of 4. But remember that when we have a power inside the brackets and a power outside the brackets, we multiply them.
explanations.B: 5 x 5 can also be written as 5². To find 5² to the power of 4, we multiply the powers together giving 2 x 4 = 8. Or we can write it as (5 x 5) x (5 x 5) x (5 x 5) x (5 x 5) = 5⁸. Dividing by 5 gives 5⁷, because when we divide we subtract the powers so 5⁸ ÷ 5 = 5⁸ ÷ 5¹ = 5⁽⁸⁻¹⁾ = 5⁷. Therefore n is 7.
explanations.C: 5⁴ ÷ 5 is 5³ but we have (5 x 5) to the power of 4. Try writing 5 x 5 as a power of 5 inside the brackets first. Then when we have a power inside the brackets and a power outside, we can multiply the powers together.
explanations.D: 5 x 5⁴ ÷ 5 is 5⁴ but we have (5 x 5)⁴ ÷ 5. Try writing 5 x 5 as a power of 5 inside the brackets first. Then when we have a power inside the brackets and a power outside, we can multiply the powers together.

explanations.A: 7⁶ ÷ 7 is 7⁵ but we have (7 x 7)⁶ ÷ 7. Try writing 7 x 7 as a power of 7 inside the brackets first. Then when we have a power inside the brackets and a power outside, we can multiply the powers together.
explanations.B: 7 x 7⁶ ÷ 7 is 7⁶ but we have (7 x 7)⁶ ÷ 7. Try writing 7 x 7 as a power of 7 inside the brackets first. Then when we have a power inside the brackets and a power outside, we can multiply the powers together.
explanations.C: I think you might have written 7 x 7 as 7² and then added the powers when raising this to the power of 6. But remember that when we have a power inside the brackets and a power outside the brackets, we multiply them.
explanations.D: 7 x 7 can also be written as 7². To find 7² to the power of 6, we multiply the powers together giving 2 x 6 = 12. Or we can write it as (7 x 7) x (7 x 7) x (7 x 7) x (7 x 7) x (7 x 7) x (7 x 7) = 7¹². Dividing by 7 gives 7¹¹, because when we divide we subtract the powers so 7¹² ÷ 7 = 7¹² ÷ 7¹ = 7⁽¹²⁻¹⁾ = 7¹¹. Therefore n is 11.

explanations.A: We only have one q in the question, so the q can't be cubed. Think carefully about the number of letter p's and the number of letter q's in the question. Writing each term out in full can help.
explanations.B: 5p² can be written 5 x p x p and 2pq as 2 x p x q. As multiplication is commutative, the order of the calculation does not matter. So we can do 5 x 2 x p x p x p x q. This gives us 10p³q.
explanations.C: Remember we are multiplying the terms, so to find the coefficient for our answer we need to multiply the 5 and the 2.
explanations.D: We can simplify this expression by multiplying the terms together. If you aren't sure, think about 5p² as being 5 x p x p and 2pq as being 2 x p x q and go from there!

explanations.A: 3p² can be written 3 x p x p and pq as p x q. So we can do 3 x p x p x p x q. This gives us 3p³q.
explanations.B: We only have one q in the question, so the q can't be squared. Think carefully about the number of letter p's and the number of letter q's in the question. Writing each term out in full can help.
explanations.C: If you have brackets around the pq then you are squaring p and q. However, we only have one q in the question. Try writing each term out in full before you multiply. For example 3p² = 3 x p x p.
explanations.D: We can simplify this expression by multiplying the terms together. If you aren't sure, think about 3p² as being 3 x p x p and pq as being p x q and go from there!
